titleStmt.title: Prières, formule de mariage des Chrétiens, en portugais et en malabar ou tamul de la côte de Coromandel

repository.orgName: Bibliothèque nationale de France. Département des Manuscrits

summary.p: It is a manuscript in Portuguese, Tamil, and Latin language containing different Christian prayers and religious principles. Some of the Portuguese texts are tranlsated into Tamil which are also glossed in Portuguese in interlinear position. It also contains Latin calendar, solar timing, and Zodiacal signs.
Description based on the online digitized version.

layoutDesc.layout: The text occupies the full page. Titles may have a bigger size and/or be preceded and followed by a drawing similar to paraph. The number of lines per page is variable.

desc.p: Periya Ra ற has double loop.
Long ā and ra are not differentiated.
Long ē and ō are not regularly differentiated from the short ones. Sometimes a diacritic consisting in an horizontal stroke is placed above the C followed by the long vowel.
The Tamil script is from an European hand.
Small drawing like paraph mark the beginning or the end of a text.
Another paratext, typical of Christian manuscript, is the cross placed in the upper margin of folio recto in centered position or at the left margin.

p.emph: Prières, formule de mariage des Chrétiens, en portugais et en malabar ou tamul de la côte de Coromandel

desc.p: The stamp is a red circle containing an eagle and the writing Bibliothèque Impérial. This is the stamp in use from 1804 to 1815 (cf. stamp n. 18 in Josserand and Bruno 1960: 281).
It is found at p. 1 and at page 70 of U1a and at p. 91 and page 139 of U6f.

p.p: Brown leather cover. Decorated cover. Title, decoration, and shelfmark on the spine. Blue marbled protective leaf.
Three different booklets and some single folios are gathered together.

origin.origDate: Different internal date only found in U6: 23 January 1740; 1745; 1756. Dated to 1756 by Cabaton (1912: 105) on unstated grounds.

acquisition.p: Anquetil-Duperron, who had reached Pondicherry in 1755 and had returned to Paris in 1761 (Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1991: 383), trasnferred 180 oriental manuscript to the BnF in 1762 (Berthier 2000: 60). His other manuscripts entered the library after his death in 1805 (Colas and Colas-Chauhan 1995: 12).

p.p: Transliteration conventions ― conservative. Irregularly marked puḷḷi, ō and ē restored only when the lenght is marked in the manuscript through a diacritic corresponding to an horizontal stroke above the C followed by a long vowel. In the Tamil transcription of Incipit and Excipit has been maintained the comma originally used for marking the word bound. ―
Abbreviations ― C = consonant, f. = folio, ff. = folios, r = recto, U/u = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.
